title: Latin Americans
text:
Latin Americans (; ; ) are the <a href="citizenship">citizens</a> of <a href="Latin%20America">Latin America</a>n countries (or people with cultural, ancestral or <a href="national%20origin">national origin</a>s in Latin America). Latin American countries and their diasporas are <a href="Multiracial%20people">multi-ethnic</a> and <a href="Multiracial%20people">multi-racial</a>. Latin Americans are a <a href="Panethnicity">pan-ethnicity</a> consisting of people of different ethnic and national backgrounds. As a result, some Latin Americans do not take their nationality as an <a href="Ethnic%20group">ethnicity</a>, but identify themselves with a combination of their <a href="nationality">nationality</a>, ethnicity and their ancestral origins. Aside from the Indigenous <a href="Indigenous%20peoples%20of%20the%20Americas">Amerindian</a> population, all Latin Americans have some <a href="Old%20World">Old World</a> ancestors who arrived since 1492. Latin America has the largest diasporas of <a href="Spanish%20diaspora">Spaniards</a>, <a href="Portuguese%20people%23Portuguese%20diaspora">Portuguese</a>, <a href="African%20diaspora">black Africans</a>, <a href="Italian%20diaspora">Italians</a>, <a href="Lebanese%20diaspora">Lebanese</a> and <a href="Japanese%20diaspora">Japanese</a> in the world. The region also has large <a href="German%20diaspora">German</a> (second largest after the United States), <a href="French%20diaspora">French</a>, <a href="Palestinian%20diaspora">Palestinian</a> (largest outside the Arab states), <a href="Chinese%20diaspora">Chinese</a> and <a href="Jewish%20diaspora">Jewish diaspora</a>s.
The specific <a href="Ethnic%20group">ethnic</a> and/or <a href="Race%20%28human%20categorization%29">racial</a> composition varies from country to country and diaspora community to diaspora community: many have a predominance of European-Amerindian or <a href="mestizo">mestizo</a>, population; in others, <a href="Indigenous%20peoples%20of%20the%20Americas">Amerindians</a> are a majority; some are mostly inhabited by people of <a href="White%20Latin%20Americans">European</a> ancestry; others are primarily <a href="mulatto">mulatto</a>. Various <a href="Afro%E2%80%93Latin%20Americans">black</a>, <a href="Asian%20Latin%20Americans">Asian</a> and <a href="zambo">zambo</a> (mixed black and Amerindian) minorities are also identified in most countries. The largest single group are <a href="White%20Latin%20Americans">white Latin Americans</a>. Together with the people of part European ancestry, they combine for almost the totality of the population.
Latin Americans and their descendants can be found almost everywhere in the world, particularly in densely populated urban areas. The most important migratory destinations for Latin Americans are found in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, <a href="Spain">Spain</a>, <a href="Canada">Canada</a>, <a href="Italy">Italy</a> and <a href="Japan">Japan</a>.
Definition.
Latin America ( or "Latinoamérica"; ; ) is the <a href="region">region</a> of the <a href="Americas">Americas</a> where <a href="Romance%20languages">Romance languages</a> (i.e., those derived from <a href="Latin%20language">Latin</a>)—particularly <a href="Spanish%20language">Spanish</a> and <a href="Portuguese%20language">Portuguese</a>, as well as <a href="French%20language">French</a>—are primarily spoken.
It includes 21 countries or territories: <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a> in <a href="North%20America">North America</a>; <a href="Guatemala">Guatemala</a>, <a href="Honduras">Honduras</a>, <a href="El%20Salvador">El Salvador</a>, <a href="Nicaragua">Nicaragua</a>, <a href="Costa%20Rica">Costa Rica</a> and <a href="Panama">Panama</a> in <a href="Central%20America">Central America</a>; <a href="Colombia">Colombia</a>, <a href="Venezuela">Venezuela</a>, <a href="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>, <a href="Peru">Peru</a>, <a href="Bolivia">Bolivia</a>, <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a>, <a href="Paraguay">Paraguay</a>, <a href="Chile">Chile</a>, <a href="Argentina">Argentina</a> and <a href="Uruguay">Uruguay</a> in <a href="South%20America">South America</a>; and <a href="Cuba">Cuba</a>, <a href="Haiti">Haiti</a>, the <a href="Dominican%20Republic">Dominican Republic</a> and <a href="Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</a> in the <a href="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>—in summary, <a href="Hispanic%20America">Hispanic America</a>, plus <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a>, and <a href="Haiti">Haiti</a>. <a href="Canada">Canada</a> and the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, despite having a sizeable Romance-speaking communities, are almost never included in the definition, primarily for being predominantly English-speaking <a href="Anglosphere">Anglosphere</a> countries.
Latin America, therefore, can be defined as all those parts of the <a href="Americas">Americas</a> that were once part of the <a href="Spanish%20Empire">Spanish</a>, <a href="Portuguese%20Empire">Portuguese</a> or <a href="French%20Colonial%20Empire">French</a> colonial empires, namely <a href="Spanish%20America">Spanish America</a>, <a href="Colonial%20Brazil">Colonial Brazil</a> and <a href="New%20France">New France</a>.
Demographics.
Ethnic and Racial groups.
The population of Latin America comprises a variety of ancestries, ethnic groups, and races, making the region one of the most diverse in the world. The specific composition varies from country to country: many have a predominance of European-Amerindian, or <a href="mestizo">mestizo</a>, population; in others, <a href="Indigenous%20peoples%20of%20the%20Americas">Amerindian</a> are a majority; some are dominated by inhabitants of <a href="white%20Latin%20Americans">European</a> ancestry; and some countries' populations are primarily <a href="mulatto">mulatto</a>. <a href="Afro-Latin%20Americans">black</a>, <a href="Asian%20Latin%20Americans">Asian</a>, and <a href="zambo">zambo</a> (mixed black and Amerindian) minorities are also identified regularly. <a href="White%20Latin%20Americans">White Latin Americans</a> are the largest single group, accounting for more than one-third of the population.

Language.
<a href="Spanish%20language">Spanish</a> and <a href="Portuguese%20language">Portuguese</a> are the predominant languages of Latin America. <a href="Spanish%20language">Spanish</a> is the official language of most of the countries on the Latin American mainland, as well as in <a href="Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</a> (where it is co-official with English), <a href="Cuba">Cuba</a> and the <a href="Dominican%20Republic">Dominican Republic</a>. <a href="Portuguese%20language">Portuguese</a> is spoken only in <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a>, the biggest and most populous country in the region. <a href="French%20language">French</a> is spoken in <a href="Haiti">Haiti</a>, as well as in the <a href="French%20overseas%20departments">French overseas departments</a> of <a href="French%20Guiana">French Guiana</a> in South America and <a href="Guadeloupe">Guadeloupe</a> and <a href="Martinique">Martinique</a> in the Caribbean. <a href="Dutch%20language">Dutch</a> is the official language of some Caribbean islands and in <a href="Suriname">Suriname</a> on the continent; however, as Dutch is a <a href="Germanic%20languages">Germanic language</a>, these territories are not considered part of Latin America.
<a href="Amerindian%20languages">Amerindian languages</a> are widely spoken in <a href="Peru">Peru</a>, <a href="Guatemala">Guatemala</a>, <a href="Bolivia">Bolivia</a>, <a href="Paraguay">Paraguay</a>, and to a lesser degree, in <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>, <a href="Chile">Chile</a> and <a href="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>. In Latin American countries not named above, the population of speakers of indigenous languages is small or non-existent.
In <a href="Peru">Peru</a>, <a href="Quechua%20languages">Quechua</a> is an official language, alongside Spanish and any other indigenous language in the areas where they predominate. In <a href="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>, while holding no official status, the closely related <a href="Quichua">Quichua</a> is a recognized language of the indigenous people under the country's constitution; however, it is only spoken by a few groups in the country's highlands. In <a href="Bolivia">Bolivia</a>, <a href="Aymara%20language">Aymara</a>, Quechua and Guaraní hold official status alongside Spanish. <a href="Guaran%C3%AD%20language">Guarani</a> is, along with Spanish, an official language of <a href="Paraguay">Paraguay</a>, and is spoken by a majority of the population (who are, for the most part, bilingual), and it is co-official with Spanish in the <a href="Argentina">Argentine</a> province of <a href="Corrientes">Corrientes</a>. In <a href="Nicaragua">Nicaragua</a>, Spanish is the official language, but, on the country's Caribbean coast <a href="English%20language">English</a> and indigenous languages such as <a href="Miskito%20language">Miskito</a>, <a href="Sumo%20languages">Sumo</a>, and <a href="Rama%20language">Rama</a> also hold official status. <a href="Colombia">Colombia</a> recognizes all indigenous languages spoken within its territory as official, though fewer than 1% of its population are native speakers of these. <a href="Nahuatl">Nahuatl</a> is one of the 62 native languages spoken by indigenous people in <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a> that are officially recognized by the government as "national languages" along with Spanish.
Other European languages spoken in Latin America include: <a href="English%20language">English</a>, by some groups in <a href="Argentina">Argentina</a>, <a href="Costa%20Rica">Costa Rica</a>, <a href="Nicaragua">Nicaragua</a>, <a href="Panama">Panama</a> and <a href="Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</a>, as well as in nearby countries that may or may not be considered Latin American, such as <a href="Belize">Belize</a> and <a href="Guyana">Guyana</a>; English is also used as a major foreign language in Latin American commerce and education. Other languages spoken in parts of Latin America include <a href="German%20language">German</a> in southern <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a>, southern <a href="Chile">Chile</a>, Argentina, portions of northern <a href="Venezuela">Venezuela</a> and Paraguay; <a href="Italian%20language">Italian</a> in Brazil, Argentina, <a href="Uruguay">Uruguay</a> and Venezuela; <a href="Polish%20language">Polish</a>, <a href="Ukrainian%20language">Ukrainian</a> and <a href="Russian%20language">Russian</a> in southern Brazil; and <a href="Welsh%20language">Welsh</a> in southern Argentina. Hebrew and Yiddish are used by Jewish diasporas in Argentina and Brazil.
In several nations, especially in the <a href="Caribbean">Caribbean</a> region, <a href="creole%20languages">creole languages</a> are spoken. The most widely spoken creole language in the Caribbean and Latin America in general is <a href="Haitian%20Creole">Haitian Creole</a>, the predominant language of <a href="Haiti">Haiti</a>; it is derived primarily from French and certain <a href="West%20Africa">West Africa</a>n tongues with <a href="Amerindian">Amerindian</a>, English, Portuguese and Spanish influences as well. Creole languages of mainland Latin America, similarly, are derived from European languages and various African tongues.
Religion.
The vast majority of Latin Americans are <a href="Christianity">Christians</a> (90%), mostly <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Church">Roman Catholics</a>. About 71% of the Latin American population consider themselves Catholic. Membership in <a href="Protestantism">Protestant</a> denominations is increasing, particularly in <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a>, <a href="Guatemala">Guatemala</a> and <a href="Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</a>. <a href="Argentina">Argentina</a> hosts the largest communities of both <a href="Jews%20in%20Argentina">Jews</a> and <a href="Islam%20in%20Argentina">Muslims</a> in Latin America. <a href="Native%20American%20religion">Indigenous religions and rituals</a> are practiced in countries with large Amerindian populations, especially Bolivia, Guatemala, Mexico and Peru, and Afro-Latin American religions such as <a href="Santer%C3%ADa">Santería</a>, <a href="Candombl%C3%A9">Candomblé</a>, <a href="Umbanda">Umbanda</a>, <a href="Macumba">Macumba</a> and <a href="Haitian%20Vodou">Vodou</a> are practiced in countries with large Afro-Latin American populations, especially Cuba, Brazil and Haiti. Latin America constitutes, in absolute terms, the <a href="Christianity%20by%20country">world's second largest Christian population</a>, after <a href="Europe">Europe</a>.
Migration.
According to the 2005 Colombian census or DANE, about 3,331,107 Colombians currently live abroad. The number of Brazilians living overseas is estimated at about 2 million people. An estimated 1.5 to two million Salvadorians reside in the United States. At least 1.5 million Ecuadorians have gone abroad, mainly to the United States and Spain. Approximately 1.5 million Dominicans live abroad, mostly in the United States. More than 1.3 million Cubans live abroad, most of them in the United States. It is estimated that over 800,000 Chileans live abroad, mainly in Argentina, Canada, United States and Spain. Other Chilean nationals may be located in countries like Costa Rica, Mexico and Sweden. An estimated 700,000 Bolivians were living in Argentina as of 2006 and another 33,000 in the United States. Central Americans living abroad in 2005 were 3,314,300, of which 1,128,701 were <a href="El%20Salvador">Salvadorans</a>, 685,713 were <a href="Guatemala">Guatemala</a>ns, 683,520 were <a href="Nicaraguans">Nicaraguans</a>, 414,955 were <a href="Hondurans">Hondurans</a>, 215,240 were <a href="Panama">Panama</a>nians and 127,061 were <a href="Costa%20Rica">Costa Rica</a>.
As of 2006, <a href="Costa%20Rica">Costa Rica</a> and <a href="Chile">Chile</a> were the only two countries with global positive migration rates.
